required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Psychometric Testing and Cue Utilization During Cued Visual Search
clinical_study.official_title: Psychometric Testing and Cue Utilization During Cued Visual Search

brief_summary.textblock: The experimenters will examine the relationship between utilization of positive (target cue) and negative (distractor cue) templates during a cued visual search task with performance on a set of measures related to executive functions associated with attentional control: shifting, updating, and inhibition.

detailed_description.textblock: The experimenters will utilize the typical procedures for the cued attentional task, while also deploying the Miyake executive function analysis. Data will also include a working memory capacity measure.

primary_outcome.measure: Positive, Negative, Neutral Attention Task Performance Speed
primary_outcome.description: Reaction times on visual search task with positive, negative, and neutral cues

primary_outcome.measure: Positive, Negative, Neutral Attention Task Performance Accuracy
primary_outcome.description: Accuracy on visual search task with positive, negative, and neutral cues
Estimate of working memory capacity based on behavioral performance

arm_group.description: All participants will complete a series of behavioral tasks, including cued visual search with positive, negative, and neutral cues, Miyake executive attention tasks, and a visual working memory task. Single Arm.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Normal or corrected-to-normal visual acuity, normal color vision
Exclusion Criteria:
- age

reference.citation: Arita JT, Carlisle NB, Woodman GF. Templates for rejection: configuring attention to ignore task-irrelevant features. J Exp Psychol Hum Percept Perform. 2012 Jun;38(3):580-4. doi: 10.1037/a0027885. Epub 2012 Apr 2.

Miyake A, Friedman NP, Emerson MJ, Witzki AH, Howerter A, Wager TD. The unity and diversity of executive functions and their contributions to complex "Frontal Lobe" tasks: a latent variable analysis. Cogn Psychol. 2000 Aug;41(1):49-100.

patient_data.ipd_description: Anonymous behavioral performance data will be available for other researchers upon request
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Upon publication of the work, for at least 5 years
